Questions?

Here are some resources I mentioned in the video:

Firefox as a browser

Why Firefox? It's actually an open-source project, you can see most of the code here: https://github.com/mozilla

Spacing lines between code

You can also have a look at code examples in this article from MDN Web Docs. You see that they use more empty lines around comments in the first example. In the second example, there are no empty lines. So it really boils down to readability. And main concern is to maintain correct indentation.

How to turn off autocompletion and selection in Visual Studio Code

You go to Code/Preferences/Settings/Text editor/Suggestions/Edit settings.json and you add these lines before the ending }
"editor.quickSuggestions": false, "editor.suggestOnTriggerCharacters": false, "editor.wordBasedSuggestions": false, "editor.parameterHints.enabled": false
Here's the Visual Studio Code documentation.

What's xhtml?

https://www.w3schools.com/tags/att_html_xmlns.asp https://www.w3schools.com/html/html_xhtml.asp https://www.w3schools.com/xml/xml_whatis.asp

https://www.w3schools.com/css/css_text.asp

3. Add styles to your first website.

Use:

  • Id selector

Link to the website:

https://hharen.github.io/mltc_webdev_course/

Your tasks

1. Have a look at the website. Think about how is it structured. What sections will you use? What elements? 2. Make a sketch of the website, pen and paper version is good enough. 3. Try to recreate the website yourself, start with the easy things. 4. You can start to prepare your content, but remember not to get stuck with it, the goal here is to practice HTML and CSS elements, not to make all the content perfect ;)   Enjoy and have fun. We'll go through the website building process in the next videos but I really encourage you to try by yourselves. If you'd get stuck, drop a question in our Slack channel.

Questions?

Ask on Slack or write your question down here:

Link to the website:

https://hharen.github.io/mltc_webdev_course/

Your tasks

1. Create a new folder for your website with the HTML file. Use the HTML5 boilerplate and change the title. 2. Add the sections and content into the body tag. For now, you can leave out the header part with menu and hero image, use just h1 tag. 3. Add the picture.

Video

Cheatsheet

Here you have cheatsheet with basic html elements. You can save it or print it. Check your HTML and CSS with these validators:
  • HTML validator
  • CSS validator

Where to find colour combinations

https://color.adobe.com/ https://colorhunt.co/ https://www.canva.com/colors/color-palettes/

Where to find attribution free pictures for personal and commercial use

https://unsplash.com https://pixabay.com

Useful resources

  • MDN web docs - Course about web development from Mozilla developers
  • W3 Schools - useful information when you need to check some html tags or css attributes and properties
  • Visual Code Studio Shortcut references
  • ISO language code reference:
  • Codepen - A great place to play with CSS and HTML code (free, requires registration)

A short dictionary of special characters

()    parentheses { }     curly brackets, curly braces [ ]     square braces < >     angle brackets -     dash, hyphen, minus _     underscore ‘ ‘     single quotes “ “     double quotes /     slash \     backslash =     equal sign #     dash |     pipe :     colon ;    semicolon ,     coma .     dot, period, full stop

Here is the codepen with the sticky navigation example. Remember, there are two classes you could apply, 'sticky' and 'fixed', depending on if you have some elements before the navigation or not. MDN on positioning.

Weather app design from Ellie and her other CSS art.

Note

Internet is a wide space there are many browsers with various versions there. Some CSS or HTML features may not work for all of them but that could be also okay. This is also a case for value 'sticky'. If you want, you can check which browsers support various attributes and values.
